00027 #ifndef _ringb_h
00028 #define _ringb_h
00029 
00030 #include <sys/types.h>
00031 #include <stdlib.h>
00032 #include <string.h>
00033 #include <bufvec.h>
00034 
00035 typedef struct
00036 {
00037     char *buf;
00038     size_t len;
00039 } ringb_data_t;
00040 
00041 typedef struct
00042 {
00043     char *buf;
00044     size_t wptr,
00045            rptr,
00046            size,
00047            mask;
00048 } ringb_t;
00049 
00050 typedef struct
00051 {
00052     float *buf;
00053     size_t len;
00054 } ringb_floatdata_t;
00055 
00056 typedef struct
00057 {
00058     float *buf;
00059     size_t wptr,
00060            rptr,
00061            size,
00062            mask;
00063 } ringb_float_t;
00064 
00065 /* Sets up a ringbuffer data structure of a specified size
00066  * and allocates the required memory.  
00067  * sz is requested ringbuffer size in bytes(floats),
00068  * MUST be a power of 2.
00069  * pre-allocated memory must be large enough to
00070  * accommodate (ringb header + stipulated memory size).
00071  * return a pointer to a new ringb_t, if successful,
00072  * 0 otherwise.
00073  * Freeing is done by calling ringb_free. */
00074 
00075 extern ringb_t *ringb_create( size_t sz2 );
00076 extern ringb_float_t *ringb_float_create( size_t sz2 );
00077 
00078 // free the ring buffers
00079 
00080 extern void ringb_free( ringb_t * rb );
00081 extern void ringb_float_free( ringb_float_t * rb );
00082 
00083 /* Fill a data structure with a description of the current readable
00084  * data held in the ringbuffer.  This description is returned in a two
00085  * element array of ringb_data_t.  Two elements are needed
00086  * because the data to be read may be split across the end of the
00087  * ringbuffer.
00088  *
00089  * The first element will always contain a valid len field, which
00090  * may be zero or greater.  If the len field is non-zero, then data
00091  * can be read in a contiguous fashion using the address given in the
00092  * corresponding @a buf field.
00093  *
00094  * If the second element has a non-zero len field, then a second
00095  * contiguous stretch of data can be read from the address given in
00096  * its corresponding buf field.
00097  *
00098  *rb a pointer to the ringbuffer structure.
00099  *vec a pointer to a 2 element array of ringb_data_t. */
00100 
00101 extern void ringb_get_read_vector( const ringb_t * rb, ringb_data_t * vec );
00102 
00103 /* Fill a data structure with a description of the current writable
00104  * space in the ringbuffer.  The description is returned in a two
00105  * element array of ringb_data_t.  Two elements are needed
00106  * because the space available for writing may be split across the end
00107  * of the ringbuffer.
00108  * The first element will always contain a valid len field, which
00109  * may be zero or greater.  If the @a len field is non-zero, then data
00110  * can be written in a contiguous fashion using the address given in
00111  * the corresponding buf field.
00112  * If the second element has a non-zero len field, then a second
00113  * contiguous stretch of data can be written to the address given in
00114  * the corresponding buf field.
00115  *rb a pointer to the ringbuffer structure.
00116  *vec a pointer to a 2 element array of ringb_data_t. */
00117 
00118 extern void ringb_get_write_vector( const ringb_t * rb, ringb_data_t * vec );
00119 
00120 /*
00121  * Read data from the ringbuffer.
00122  *rb a pointer to the ringbuffer structure.
00123  * dest a pointer to a buffer where data read from the
00124  * ringbuffer will go.
00125  * cnt the number of bytes to read.
00126  * return the number of bytes read, which may range from 0 to cnt. */
00127 
00128 extern size_t ringb_read( ringb_t * rb, char *dest, size_t cnt );
00129 extern size_t ringb_float_read( ringb_float_t * rb, float *dest, size_t cnt );
00130 
00131 /* Read data from the ringbuffer. Opposed to ringb_read()
00132  * this function does not move the read pointer. Thus it's
00133  * a convenient way to inspect data in the ringbuffer in a
00134  * continous fashion. The price is that the data is copied
00135  * into a user provided buffer. For "raw" non-copy inspection
00136  * of the data in the ringbuffer use ringb_get_read_vector().
00137  * rb a pointer to the ringbuffer structure.
00138  * dest a pointer to a buffer where data read from the
00139  *   ringbuffer will go.
00140  * cnt the number of bytes to read.
00141  * return the number of bytes read, which may range from 0 to cnt.
00142  */
00143 
00144 extern size_t ringb_peek( ringb_t * rb, char *dest, size_t cnt );
00145 
00146 /* Advance the read pointer.
00147  * After data have been read from the ringbuffer using the pointers
00148  * returned by ringb_get_read_vector(), use this function to
00149  * advance the buffer pointers, making that space available for future
00150  * write operations.
00151  * rb a pointer to the ringbuffer structure.
00152  * cnt the number of bytes read. */
00153 
00154 extern void ringb_read_advance( ringb_t * rb, size_t cnt );
00155 
00156 /* Return the number of bytes available for reading.
00157  *rb a pointer to the ringbuffer structure.
00158  * return the number of bytes available to read. */
00159 
00160 extern size_t ringb_read_space( const ringb_t * rb );
00161 extern size_t ringb_float_read_space( const ringb_float_t * rb );
00162 
00163 /* Reset the read and write pointers, making an empty buffer.
00164  * This is not thread safe. */
00165 
00166 extern void ringb_reset( ringb_t * rb );
00167 extern void ringb_float_reset( ringb_float_t * rb );
00168 
00169 /* Write data into the ringbuffer.
00170  *rb a pointer to the ringbuffer structure.
00171  * src a pointer to the data to be written to the ringbuffer.
00172  * cnt the number of bytes(floats) to write.
00173  * return the number of bytes(floats) written, which may range from 0 to cnt */
00174 
00175 extern size_t ringb_write( ringb_t * rb, const char *src, size_t cnt );
00176 extern size_t ringb_float_write( ringb_float_t * rb, const float *src,
00177                                  size_t cnt );
00178 
00179 /* Advance the write pointer.
00180  * After data have been written the ringbuffer using the pointers
00181  * returned by ringb_get_write_vector(), use this function
00182  * to advance the buffer pointer, making the data available for future
00183  * read operations.
00184  * rb a pointer to the ringbuffer structure.
00185  * cnt the number of bytes written. */
00186 
00187 extern void ringb_write_advance( ringb_t * rb, size_t cnt );
00188 
00189 /* Return the number of bytes(floats) available for writing.
00190  *rb a pointer to the ringbuffer structure.
00191  * return the amount of free space (in bytes) available for writing. */
00192 
00193 extern size_t ringb_write_space( const ringb_t * rb );
00194 extern size_t ringb_float_write_space( const ringb_float_t * rb );
00195 
00196 /* Fill the ring buffer for nbytes at the beginning with zeros 
00197  * rb a pointer to the ring buffer structure
00198  * nbytes the number of bytes to be written */
00199 
00200 extern void ringb_clear( ringb_t * rb, size_t nbytes );
00201 extern void ringb_float_clear( ringb_float_t * rb, size_t nfloats );
00202 
00203 /* Reset the read and write pointers, making an empty buffer.
00204  * This is not thread safe. 
00205  * Fill the ring buffer for nbytes at the beginning with zeros 
00206  * rb a pointer to the ring buffer structure
00207  * nbytes the number of bytes to be written */
00208 
00209 extern void ringb_restart( ringb_t * rb, size_t nbytes );
00210 extern void ringb_float_restart( ringb_float_t * rb, size_t nfloats );
00211 
00212 #endif /*  */
